gw.pl.util

Class Rectangle

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.pl.util.Rectangle

  • public class Rectangle
extends java.lang.Object
    A class representing a Rectangle in two-dimensional co-ordinate space, where the sides of the Rectangle are parallel with the x and y axes.

    • Field Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Rectangle(int minX, int minY, int maxX, int maxY)
      Creates a rectangle containing the points (x,y) such that x >= minX and x < maxX and y >= minY and y < maxY

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if minX > maxX or minY > maxY

      • shatterWithRectangle

        public Rectangle[] shatterWithRectangle(Rectangle newRectangle,
                               int fusionStrategy)
        This method returns an array of Rectangles with the following properties:

        1. no two rectangles in the array intersect

        2. every rectangle in the array is contained in this

        3. no rectangle in the array intersects with r2

        4. every point contained in this is either contained in r2, or is contained in one of the rectangles in the array.

        5. every rectangle's minX and maxX values are among (this.minX, this.maxX, r2.minX, r2.maxX)

        6. every rectangle's minY and maxY values are among (this.minY, this.maxY, r2.minY, r2.maxY)

        If the fusion strategy is NO_FUSION, then the methods returns largest possible array of rectangles that meet the above requirements. Every rectangle must share at least one vertex with r2. Every vertex of r2 that is contained within this must be shared by three rectangles in the array.

        If the fusion stratey is FUSE_VERTICALLY, then the returned array may contain no two rectangles r1 r2 such that r1.touchesVertically(v2)

        If the fusion stratey is FUSE_HORIZONTALLY, then the returned array may contain no two rectangles r1 r2 such that r1.touchesHorizontally(v2)

        Here is an example: 

          A          J             K       B
   +---------+-------------+------+
   |         |             |      |
   |        E|             |F     |
 R +---------+-------------+------+ L
   |         |             |      |
   |         |             |      |
 Q +---------+-------------+------+ M
   |        H|             |G     |
   |         |             |      |
   |         |             |      |
   +---------+-------------+------+
 D           P             N       C

        If this = ABCD and r2 = EFGH, then a fusion strategy of NO_FUSION would return the eight smallest rectangles outside EFGH. A fusion strategy of FUSE_VERTICALLY would return four rectangles: AJPD, JKFE, KBCN and HGPN. A fusion strategy of FUSE_HORIZONTALLY would return four rectangles: would return four rectangles: ABLR, LMGF, QMCD and REHQ.

        If this = RFND and r2 = JBMH, then a fusion strategy of NO_FUSION would return the three small rectangles REHQ,QHPD and HGNP. A fusion strategy of FUSE_VERTICALLY would return two rectangles: REPD and HGNP. A fusion strategy of FUSE_HORIZONTALLY would return two rectangles: REHQ and QGND.

        Parameters:
        newRectangle - another Rectangle
        fusionStrategy - one of NO_FUSION, FUSE_HORIZONTALLY and FUSE_VERTICALLY
        Returns:
        an array of fragments generated by intersecting r2 with this Rectangle as described above, or null if r2 does not intersect with this. Fusion is performed on the fragments according to the given strategy before they are returned.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()

      • touchesHorizontally

        public boolean touchesHorizontally(Rectangle r2)
        Parameters:
        r2 - another Rectangle
        Returns:
        true iff there is is a point (x,y) contained in this such that (x+1,y) is contained in r2.

      • touchesVertically

        public boolean touchesVertically(Rectangle r2)
        Parameters:
        r2 - another Rectangle
        Returns:
        true iff there is is a point (x,y) contained in this such that (x,y+1) is contained in r2.
